nodes.text: CONDA provides versatile, low-cost datapath soft error detection for HPC applications via compiler-level code transformation and static analysis

CONDA implements a holistic datapath protection approach by combining instruction duplication and software signatures through compiler transformations without disrupting original control-flow and memory access patterns
Method: Lazy Checking Motion - duplicate instructions and signatures, buffer comparison results in registers, and postpone checks to avoid inserting extra basic blocks
Method: Domination Propagation - use domination analysis to propagate and aggregate buffered checking results across basic blocks at register level, avoiding global memory load/store synchronization

Method: Adaptive Detection Placement - statically place detection branches at function exits, loop backedges, or loop exits based on outermost loop count to trade off latency and control-flow complexity

Claim: Buffering comparisons in registers and AND/OR combining per basic block preserves original control-flow (reduces dynamic basic block expansion) compared with inserting checks per DDS or per block
Claim: Register-level aggregation via domination propagation preserves memory access patterns and avoids billions of extra global memory accesses that arise from memory-based aggregation
Claim: Adaptive placement reduces detection latency substantially without requiring dynamic profiling by placing checks at function exits and appropriate loop edges

Result/Evidence: Evaluation on 38 benchmarks shows average runtime overhead 57.79%, which is 41.84% lower than the implemented baseline; dynamic basic block overhead reduced to 22.82% vs baseline 224.17%; CONDA outperforms a memory-aggregation variant (CONDA-mem) and baseline on 36/38 benchmarks

Result/Evidence: Detection latency reduced by 16.28x using adaptive detection placement compared to placing checks only at function exits, while adaptive placement adds only 4.65% additional runtime overhead on selected benchmarks

Evidence: Fault coverage from fault injection experiments matches state-of-the-art: CONDA achieves equivalent data-flow detection to EDDI and equivalent or slightly better control-flow detection than CFCSS (averaged SDC reductions reported)

Result/Evidence: CONDA is compatible with multi-threaded OpenMP HPC workloads (SimpleMOC case study) with measured runtime overheads between 46.23% and 64.23% across thread counts, and consistent fault coverage and latency in parallel runs

Conclusion: CONDA realizes holistic datapath soft error detection with substantially reduced runtime cost while preserving or improving detection effectiveness and latency, making practical deployment in HPC workloads feasible
